http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Debate I is a two-semester course that will provide students with an understanding of the dynamics of effective oral communication when speaking, listening, and responding. Students will develop basic communication competencies including ethical practices in communication; recognition of communication barriers; and effective use of interpersonal communication, listening, verbal and nonverbal messages, and use of digital media. The life skills listed in Strand 4: Communication Competencies will be embedded throughout the course. Further, students in Debate I will gain an understanding of the fundamentals of argumentation and will express ideas and present information in a variety of oral advocacy situations from small group discussions to formal debates. Special emphasis will be given to research proficiencies and analytical thinking and listening skills.
Preparation
Students will read and collect research from textual evidence to prepare for debates.
Prepare for a variety of debates

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., impromptu, international public, legal, legislative, Lincoln Douglas, parliamentary, policy, public forum)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Analyze current events and political atmosphere

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., domestic policy, economic policy, foreign policy, social climate)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Collaborate to define issues and develop strategies

Research arguments to support substantive claims using a variety of primary and/or secondary sources including but not limited to historical, scientific, and technical texts:
  • central idea
  • discrepancies in content
  • explanation for action or events
  • points of view
  • specialized vocabulary
  • textual evidence
Evaluate researched texts for validity, reliability, and credibility of source, content, and/or author
Procedures
Students will demonstrate understanding of the fundamentals of oral advocacy.
Compare and contrast classical and contemporary philosophers and their contributions to debate
Explain the historical and contemporary role that debate and oral advocacy play in democratic society

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., diplomacy, government policy, justice system, politics)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Discuss ethical dilemmas and practices
Demonstrate ethical practices in debate

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., behavior, courtesy, verbal and nonverbal communication)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value:
Demonstrate effective communication skills in debate:
  • listening (e.g., critical and attentive listening demonstrated by note taking, critiquing)
  • nonverbal communication (e.g., attire, eye contact, facial expressions, gestures, proximity)
  • speaking (e.g., framing questions, responding to questions, speaking extemporaneously, using appropriate language))
Analyze a variety of debate structures and purposes

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., impromptu, international public, legal, legislative, Lincoln Douglas, policy, public forum)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Use debate speech conventions in different forms of debate

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., affirmative, closing, constructive, cross examination, direct examination, negative, rebuttal, opening)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Identify debate terminology

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., agent of action, ballot, burden of proof, card, claim, counter plans, data, fiat, flow, judge, presumption, resolution, status quo, stock issues, warrant)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value:
Examine stock issues:
  • harm
  • nherency
  • significance
  • solvency
  • topicality

Apply critical thinking skills when researching, preparing, and presenting arguments:
  • causal arguments
  • logical fallacies (e.g., fallacies of language, fallacies of causation)
  • source validity (e.g., author bias, date, methodology, source bias)
Create effective teams
Presentation
Students will present debates using a variety of debate formats.
Participate in a variety of debates

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., impromptu, international public, legal, legislative, Lincoln Douglas, policy, public forum)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Identify evaluator paradigms

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., appearance, games player, policymaker, stock issues, tabula rasa)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Adjust behaviors and arguments to match audience and evaluator paradigms
Present arguments using clear and concise language
Use evidence to support analysis of topics and cases
Challenge the status quo and current policy proposals, using a variety of arguments and rhetorical devices
Demonstrate the process of refutation
Conduct cross examinations

Develop presentation skills to convey complex ideas:
  • extemporaneous speech
  • formal register
  • persuasive techniques
Critique peer debates orally and/or in writing
Communication Competencies
Students will demonstrate fundamental oral communication competencies.

Apply principles of ethical communication appropriate to context:
  • academic honesty
  • bias
  • communication responsibility
  • plagiarism
  • respect for diversity
Analyze the reduction of communication barriers

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., adversarial mindset, bias, communication apprehension, environment, noise, nonverbal communication, perception, proxemics/spatial, reticence, semantics)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value:
Demonstrate mutual respect in interpersonal communication:
  • aggressive
  • assertive
  • conflict-resolution strategies
  • passive
  • passive/aggressive
Demonstrate the ability to give and receive constructive criticism

Demonstrate appropriate critical, empathetic, appreciative, and reflective listening skills in formal and informal situations:
  • active listening behaviors
  • false assumptions
  • loaded terms
  • note-taking
  • sarcasm

Adjust messages based on feedback:
  • peer ballots and rubrics
  • teacher/evaluator ballots and rubrics
Speak while maintaining a formal style and objective tone

Critique oral messages:
  • clarity
  • effectiveness of delivery
  • faulty reasoning and logical fallacies (e.g., ad hominem, ad populum, appeal to authority, appeal to tradition, band-wagon, begging the question, fallacy of unimpeachable source, mistaken cause, name calling, post hoc ergo propter hoc, red herring, straw man)
  • organization of evidence
  • relevance

Discuss effective nonverbal communication skills:
  • attire
  • facial expressions
  • gestures
  • paralanguage (e.g., inflection, pause, pitch, rate, stress, volume)
  • platform movement
  • proxemics/spatial communication

Use context appropriate oral messages:
  • concrete expressions of thought
  • connotation vs. denotation
  • dialects
  • International Phonetic Alphabet
  • jargon
  • slang
  • standard English
  • words and symbols
